Message.Title: First 6 days with Surface Pro 128
Message.Msg: I was lucky, had a best buy hold the device and drove 3 hours away to get it last Saturday. I have installed 2013 Office, Visual Studio 2008 for app programming, SQL Server 2008, added it to my corporate domain. Also installed full version of Adobe Acrobat Pro, and Adobe Photoshop. Also, running company rmm tool software and three other proprietary applications such as connectwise. I bought an usb port extender, a displayport to vga adapter and run a second 27 inch monitor. I dropped my old laptop bag which held a 16 inch sony i5/128gb ssd machine, and now my surface simply fits in a small sachel/briefcase. Performance of the machine is unbeatable, the boot speed easily beats the sony. The Pen is simply amazing, I find I use it the most as a secondary mouse and found it especially useful and when not having it find it annoying to reach in touch the screen...which you wouldn't think..you will see what I mean when you use it a week. I was at a meeting at Panera Bread today, this location is full of business meetings in the mornings, I easily seen half dozen people having a corporate laptop right next to their ipad. Hell you need the entire table, the footprint is so small for the surface on your desk/table you have a place to work. Finally, carry one device, leave the bulky laptop at home or retire it as I have. I have been a software developer for 13 years, and I need computing power the surface has the power I need to run everything from compiling apps, running database servers for local development. I cannot say enough with how impressed I am with this tablet/laptop it has changed the way I work for the better. Corporate America will be buying these or similar windows 8 pro tablets such as the HP Envy X2. There will be full product lines of win 8 tablets from all manufactures within two years, these devices will eliminate the need to carry a "second" ipad. It will simply be in the way and be handed to the kids to play cute games.

Message.Title: all Surface pro 64 Gb are sold out at all my loacal Best Buy stores, again!!!!
Message.Msg: Looks like the Surface Pros are selling realy well. Over the last a few days, some of my local stores still had the 64 version, though no 128 version all along. However, starting today, a total of about 15 stores (Vernon Hills, IL) none of them have any now. I tried Best Buy store to order, but store pick up is about 3-5 days away. This menas sometime next week. Surface Pros, all loking good for MSFT. If 1 million of the Pros are sold this quater, and another 1 millon of the RT is sold this quater, we are looking at $1.5 billions of fresh new revenue!!!! This willput it at $6 billion on a yearly basis.

Message.Title: 45 meter Asteroid to Skirt Very Near Earth on Feb 15
Message.Msg: Some real news for a change. The object will miss Earth by about 28,000 km, which is a small fraction of the distance to the moon, but many times the depth of the Earth's atmosphere. What makes this especially interesting is how closely it follows the fall of a meteorite in Russia only yesterday. "Residents in the city of Chelyabinsk, the largest in the affected region, described a shock wave from the meteorite that blew in doors and smashed glass," according to a WSJ report. About 500 people are said to have been injured.

Message.Title: Another whopping lie by our pres
Message.Msg: The Biggest Fib Of 2013: We Have Reduced "The Deficit By More Than $2.5 Trillion" From Forbes The most shameful lie in the President’s State of the Union speech was the following claim: “Over the last few years, both parties have worked together to reduce the deficit by more than $2.5 trillion. As a result we are more than halfway toward the goal of $4 trillion in deficit reduction that economists say we need to stabilize our finances.” I was shocked by this blatant attempt to convince the nation that it is not really necessary to make cuts in Social Security and Medicare. Rather, after misrepresenting the agreement reached in the Budget Control Act of 2011 to cap domestic programs by $1.2 trillion over 10 years– most of which are on the come– not actually made– the President then went on to try and spend more money we don’t have on infrastructure (he should have done it in 2009). It sure would be helpful if we could hire people to repair 70,000 bridges, establish pre-nursery schools for every 4 year old kid, attack the environmental problems that emanate from global warming, and welcome valuable immigrants from around the globe. But, first we have to decide which domestic programs need to be capped, and obtain agreement on how to proceed in a manner that won’t result in another recession and higher unemployment. Maybe the White House intends to pay for all this by closing loopholes for fat-cat oilmen. That would be a hell of an achievement. Still, I’d rather learn precisely how and where and when and how much we have already reduced the deficit by $2.5 trillion. There’s a challenge for some enterprising journalist like myself. I’ll let you know how it comes out ASAP

Message.Title: Apple is taking the enterprise by storm
Message.Msg: Apple is an enterprise juggernaut. It had to be said. For the first time since its founding, Apple products have won broad acceptance in the in the corporate world rather than the grudging tolerance they faced through most of Apple's 36-year history. iPad is now in use by virtually all of the Fortune 500 companies and more than 85 percent of the Global 500. In some cases, those companies have widely deployed the iPad. Other enterprises are simply testing the company's slate. In either case, enterprise acceptance of Apple's iPad is a great achievement. But the iPad isn't the only Apple product that has earned corporate acceptance. The company's iPhone is being used by more enterprise customers than ever. All the while Macs have slowly but surely made inroads into the corporate world. Apple products are now common in just about any office environment one walks into. It's a testament to what Apple has become, and what Apple has done to revamp its business and reinvent how people view the company. Simply put, Apple is now an enterprise favorite. In this eWEEK slide show, we examine how Apple did it.

Topic.Title: Does anyone know what a "selp" is?

Message.Msg: "But anyone with a fair amount of grey matter will be concerned." Anyone with a fair amount of grey matter will also recall the Maunder Minimum and the Little Ice Age, and fact that they coincided with a complete absence of sunspots. Such correlations do not happen by accident.
